description: A full gas mask that covers the face and eyes.  Provides excellent protection from smoke, tear gas, and other contaminants.  It must be prepared before use.

armor.//: The cotton represents the head harness that keeps the mask attached to one’s melon. Hood-style masks, like the GP5, should get their own item.
While some older gas masks had lenses made from glass, most modern ones are fabricated with plastic eyepieces or visors. We can hand-wave away the outliers.
The exhale valve, speech diaphragm, and, if a mask has them, the communications unit and drinking tube, are located over the mouth and nose sections. They’re represented by the plastic content.
Most modern gas masks possess plastic filter mounts on either one or both of the cheek sections, which this plastic represents. Again, we can tactically handwave away the outliers.

description: A full-face gas mask rated for use in chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear-contaminated areas, built from a comfortable rubber-silicone blend and featuring a panoramic eyepiece, drinking tube, and a communications interface.  The standard gasmask of the United States military, this respirator possesses a twin-filter system incompatible with standard 40mm NATO filters.  It must be prepared before use.
//: Retail price, believe it or not. Sourced from https://www.galls.com/avon-fm50-full-face-mask-system

//2: The single-element eyepiece gives 90 degrees of vision, while the twin bayonet filter ports provide less overall resistance to breathing. The reduced encumbrance numbers reflect these features.

pocket_data.description: A number of external brackets arranged around the eyepiece to retain an outer attachment.
A space behind the visor designed to accommodate the installation of inserts.

description: Less of a piece of PPE than a giant canvas sock coated in rubber, this mask is formed from a Butyl-coated waterproof sack with eyepieces, a pair of filter ports, and inhale valves buggered from a proper respirator attached to it.  Compatible with 40mm STANAG filters, capable of housing heavily mutated anatomy, and needing to be prepared before use, this potato-sack-turned head equipment sags upon the face while its elastic mouth clamps about the neck to form a seal.  Considering the lack of an exhale valve and the lungs of the beings it’s meant for, the whole thing balloons with each breath.
//: Calculated to be formed from a 2mm sheet of 75x75 cm canvas with a density of 1600 kg/m, coated by a 0.4mm thick layer of butyl rubber with a density of 920 kg/m, with a panoramic eyepiece, two filter ports, and two intake valves attached.
The longest length is low, as, fundamentally, it’s just a giant collapsible sack. Hence, it only needs to be as long as the panoramic eyepiece potentially used to make it, give or take some length.

armor.//: Like the VM44, on which this is based, the mask is just all around floppy in the places where it isn’t pulled tight against the wearer’s skin, and, as such, it doesn’t retain its shape, unlike actual, proper gas masks.

The survivor would have likely placed the filter ports and related equipment in similar places to the actual gas masks that have a dual filter system, one on each cheek. The plastic content represents this.
armor.//2: Gas mask intake valves and filter ports aren’t designed to supply the quantity of air that an inhumanly large being would require per breath, hence the placement of two ports to increase the supply of air being dragged in at any given time and to lower overall air resistance.  That being said, the lack of an exhale valve and general structure of the mask still make breathing harder than it would be on a proper respirator.

description: A waist-length overcoat with an integral chemical hood, an expandable pocket sewn into the left sleeve, and Velcro fastenings on the wrists and zipper, this jacket forms half of the US military’s CBRN JSLIST overgarment. Constructed with an inner layer of carbon discs that keep harmful chemicals from penetrating through the suit and a selectively permeable membrane that lets perspiration escape, the garment’s meant to be either worn over a regular uniform or alone for maximum breathability. Unsealed and exposed to the elements, it will likely last a day before its carbon layer is exhausted and the PPE loses its protective nature.
//: I wasn’t able to find numbers for actual issued overcoats, but I was able to find rough statistics for the MIRA Safety MOPP-1 CBRN suit, which is functionally the same: https://www.mirasafety.com/products/cbrn-protective-mopp-suit. Material thicknesses are my best guess, which is to say I didn’t find any numbers, plugged in some values that felt about right, slapped them on a plastic lunchbox, and committed them. If you have or find better values, feel free to update accordingly.
//2: The suit’s outer shell is a 50/50 blend of nylon and cotton rip-stop material, attached to an inner lining of activated carbon discs embedded within the fabric of a selectively permeable, breathable inner membrane: https://kohantextilejournal.com/cbrn-personal-protective-clothing/. Nylon material represents, spoilers, the nylon/ synthetic fabric element, canvas represents the rip-stop woven cotton used in the suits to make it tougher, charcoal represents the carbon beeds, and lycra seemed like the best candidate to model the inner membrane.
//3: The trader avoid flag is present as the suit is, without a hermetically sealed bag, functionally a one-time consumable on a countdown timer to becoming a worse jumpsuit. While some NPCs, indeed, most NPCs, would probably not know this information, there’s no way to selectively pick and choose who does and who doesn’t.

countdown_action.message: 24 hours have passed since the coat was unpacked, and the carbon layer is now exhausted; it will no longer filter or protect you from contaminants!

damage_verb: produces an audible tearing sound, your protective layer has been breached!

use_action.msg: You flip down the chemical hood, unzip the coat, and roll up your sleeves.

description: A waist-length overcoat with an integral chemical hood, an expandable pocket sewn into the left sleeve, and Velcro fastenings on the wrists and zipper, this ripped and torn jacket used to form half of the US military’s CBRN JSLIST overgarment.  Constructed with an inner layer of carbon discs to keep harmful chemicals from penetrating through the suit and a selectively permeable membrane meant to let perspiration escape, its intended role has been rendered void by the large amounts of lacerations that coat it, allowing any biohazard to infiltrate the coat unimpeded.  It's little more than a glorified jacket at this point, and not even a particularly good one at that; you’d be better off just discarding it.
